abstract.p: Left-ventricular (LV) hypoplasia encompasses a range of LV sizes, varying from a mildly underdeveloped, but functionally adequate, chamber to the miniscule, barely perceptible LV cavity seen in hypoplastic left-heart syndrome. Associated malformations include obstructive lesions of LV inflow, outflow, and the aortic arch, often in combination. Repair of complex combinations and/or severe LV hypoplasia usually results in a single-ventricle anatomy with the right ventricle serving as the systemic ventricle. New therapeutic interventions, including fetal procedures, are expanding the spectrum of lesions and LV sizes that may be amenable to a biventricular repair. These surgical considerations place renewed emphasis on understanding the anatomical features associated with LV hypoplasia. This review details pathological features of the full spectrum of LV hypoplasia, particularly those with borderline severe hypoplasia. Primary defining lesions are described as well as additional lesions that may affect clinical symptoms, surgical repair, and long-term outcome.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Hypoplastic left-heart syndrome (HLHS) encompasses a spectrum of severe obstructive lesions on the left side of the heart that share the common feature of a left ventricle (LV) whose size is clearly inadequate to support the systemic circulation. The obstructive lesions involve LV inflow and outflow in specific combinations of mitral valve (MV) atresia/aortic valve atresia (MA/AA), MV stenosis/aortic valve atresia (MS/AA), and MV stenosis/aortic valve stenosis (MS/AS). Obstruction of the aortic arch (hypoplasia, coarctation) is common to all 3 subtypes of HLHS. When a diagnosis of HLHS is made and surgical repair pursued, the patient is started on a pathway often referred to as a “staged single ventricle repair.” In the initial Norwood procedure, outflow tract obstruction is repaired with reconstruction of the ascending aorta and arch, incorporating the pulmonary valve as the neoaortic valve. Atrial septectomy ensures pulmonary venous access to the right side of the heart. The right ventricle (RV) is designated as the systemic ventricle and a temporary shunt provides blood flow to the pulmonary circulation. After neonatal pulmonary vascular resistance has appropriately decreased, the second stage of the repair directs superior vena caval blood flow to the right and left pulmonary arteries via a modified, bidirectional Glenn shunt. Redirection of inferior vena caval blood flow away from the heart and directly to the lungs with the final stage Fontan procedure completes separation of the pulmonary and systemic circulations. In many cases, a fenestration is created between the IVC pathway and the right atrium (RA), allowing the patient to adapt to the altered hemodynamics of the Fontan circulation. Although this may result in some degree of cyanosis, the fenestration will either close spontaneously or via a percutaneous occlusion device inserted with cardiac catheterization. Each stage of this complex repair has its own attendant morbidity and mortality, and questions remain regarding the long-term outlook for the RV as the systemic ventricle.

Functional size of the LV as one of the defining criteria for HLHS, and as such for a single-ventricle repair, is controversial. This spectrum of obstructive aortic and MV lesions may be associated with a continuum of LV size, from mild to severe hypoplasia. Indeed, some consider HLHS to consist of the entire spectrum of LV hypoplasia.1 Others exclude mild LV hypoplasia, and still others, including this author, limit HLHS to the severe end of the spectrum.2-4 Difficulty in establishing an absolute size for the lower limit of LV functional viability leaves a problematic group of hearts with borderline severe LV hypoplasia and questionable functional capability. Many of these hearts undergo the staged single-ventricle repair. In some cases, surgical options now include techniques to enhance LV size and function, thereby permitting a biventricular repair in cases not previously thought possible. As such, what constitutes an LV size inadequate to support the systemic circulation may be a moving target. Furthermore, because LV hypoplasia has been demonstrated to progress in the fetal heart, intrauterine intervention may be possible to promote sufficient LV growth, permitting postnatal biventricular repair.5,6 These considerations for surgical interventions place renewed emphasis on understanding the anatomical features associated with the full spectrum of LV hypoplasia. Features that were previously insignificant to a Norwood/Fontan single-ventricle repair may have to be addressed with a biventricular repair.

This review presents the spectrum of pathological features of LV hypoplasia, ranging from mild to severe. Primary defining lesions are described as well as additional lesions that may affect clinical symptoms, surgical repair, and long-term outcome. Pathology findings presented are predominantly based on a nearly 30-year ongoing prospective and retrospective review of congenitally malformed hearts in a congenital heart museum collection at this institution. The collection spans nearly 60 years with more than 2000 hearts. In the following review, a brief historical overview is provided to explain the evolution of the term HLHS and the basis for the varied interpretations as to what lesions and LV sizes are to be included.

sec.title: Historical Perspective of HLHS
sec.p: Our understanding of HLHS as an entity began with the examination of postmortem hearts at a time when this spectrum of lesions was uniformly fatal. Individual cases and reviews of specific types of left-sided obstructive lesions had been previously published dating back to the 1850s. The broader spectrum of lesions was first recognized and grouped together as an entity in 1952 by Maurice Lev.7,8 In a review of 40 postmortem hearts, Lev described a constellation of pathological features, which he referred to as “hypoplasia of the aortic tract complexes.”8 All hearts had normal, concordant ventriculo-arterial anatomy, thereby excluding cases with transposition or double-outlet RV. A few years later, in 1958, Noonan and Nadas9 reviewed clinicopathological features of 101 pathology cases, emphasizing the similarity of the salient associated clinical features for premortem diagnosis. These authors proposed the currently favored term, hypoplastic left-heart syndrome.

However, both these historic, landmark publications included left-sided obstructive lesions associated with septal defects and mild hypoplasia of a functionally adequate LV. Indeed, the most common lesion (70%) among those reviewed by Noonan and Nadas9 was hypoplasia of the aortic arch, many with associated ventricular septal defect (VSD) and a few with atrioventricular canal defect. In 1966, Lev proposed a more restrictive definition of HLHS, excluding cases with a VSD. The central, unifying features were the presence of AA or severe AS, with marked hypoplasia of the ascending aorta.10 The LV was either minute (with MA) or a “small,” thick-walled chamber with endocardial fibroelastosis (EFE; with a patent MV). These 3 landmark articles are key to our current understanding of the pathological anatomy of HLHS. The lesions included in Lev’s more restrictive definition of HLHS represent the severe end of the spectrum of LV hypoplasia. The more broad interpretation of HLHS, to include the full spectrum of LV hypoplasia, is largely based on the review by Noonan and Nadas.9

sec.title: The Spectrum of LV Hypoplasia
sec.p: A review of pathological features of LV hypoplasia begins with external features of the heart. LV hypoplasia is indicated by leftward and superior (basal) deviation of the anterior and posterior interventricular sulci, which demarcate the size and position of the LV. These features correlate with the typically described “non–apex forming” hypoplastic LV (Figure 1A). Right-sided cardiac structures, including the RA, RV, and pulmonary artery are dilated. In addition to LV hypoplasia, the left atrium, ascending aorta, and aortic arch are variably hypoplastic, depending on the location and severity of the left-sided obstructive lesion (Figure 1B).

caption.p: A. External view of heart with HLHS. The lower arrow points to the apex of the markedly hypoplastic LV. The RA, RV, pulmonary artery (Pa), and PDA are dilated. B. The ascending aorta (arrowheads) is markedly hypoplastic in this heart with aortic valve atresia. The arrow points to a coarctation in the aortic arch (Ao) opposite the PDA.
Abbreviations: HLHS, hypoplastic left-heart syndrome; PDA, patent ductus arteriosus; LV, left ventricle; RV, right ventricle; RA, right atrium.

sec.title: Pathological Anatomy of Severe LV Hypoplasia (HLHS)
Aortic Valve
sec.p: As emphasized by Maurice Lev, the aortic valve is always either severely stenotic (AS) or atretic (AA), with a markedly hypoplastic valve annulus. The majority of cases have AA with the LV outflow tract ending blindly in a dimple (Figure 2A). When viewed from above, slight ridges suggest commissures but there is no valvular tissue. The stenotic valve has dysplastic, thickened, poorly formed cusps (Figure 2B). Bicuspid, dysplastic valves are common. Although in this author’s experience AS with a unicuspid valve is rare, others have found AS in infancy to be mostly unicuspid.11

caption.p: Left lateral views of 2 hearts with markedly hypoplastic LVs: (A) The LV outflow tract ends blindly at the atretic aortic valve (arrow) with a markedly hypoplastic ascending aorta (Ao). (B) Severe aortic stenosis with thickened dysplastic valve (arrow) and marked endocardial fibroelastosis (arrowheads).
Abbreviation: LV, left ventricle.

sec.title: Mitral Valve Apparatus
sec.p: The MV is either atretic (MA) or patent, but typically stenotic (MS). In MA, the floor of the left atrium ends blindly in a dimple (Figure 3A). In some cases, a tiny imperforate membrane can be demonstrated, but in the remainder, the entire floor of the atrium is muscular. With MA, unless there is an alternate pathway for blood flow to enter the LV, such as a VSD, the aortic valve will also be atretic (MA/AA). If the VSD is small, the heart will closely resemble HLHS; however, these hearts should be considered HLHS variants because classic HLHS has no VSD. When the MV is patent, the annulus is hypoplastic, with a size proportionate to the degree of LV hypoplasia. There is intrinsic MS with variably thickened leaflets. Chordae tendineae are also thickened, abnormally short, and partially fused (Figure 3B). In some cases, the chordae are virtually absent, with leaflets that directly insert into the papillary muscles. Papillary muscle size is also usually proportionate to the LV chamber size; however, they are often poorly formed and poorly demarcated from the LV free wall.

caption.p: A. The floor of the left atrium (LA) ends blindly at the dimple of the atretic MV (arrow). B. HLHS with thickened leaflets and chordae tendineae of dysplastic, stenotic MV (arrow). A probe enters the LA through a patent foramen ovale with a moderately thickened covering valve (asterisk).
Abbreviations: MV, mitral valve; HLHS, hypoplastic left-heart syndrome.

sec.p: In clinical reviews of HLHS with AA, the ratio of cases with MA/AA versus MS/AA is approximately 60:40.12 As reviewed by Nathan et al,12 this ratio is similar in pathology series that pre-dated the current era of Norwood and Fontan palliation.12 These authors further noted that more recent pathology series describe a higher percentage of HLHS with MS, with an MA/AA:MS/AA ratio that is either 50:50 or reversed at 40:60. This apparent increased mortality in HLHS with MS in the current surgically treated era suggests associated features that negatively affect successful surgical intervention in this subgroup. Several of these potential features are described below.

sec.title: Left Ventricle
sec.p: LV size and morphology largely correlate with the anatomy of the aortic valve and MV. If both valves are atretic—MA/AA—the LV is a miniscule, sequestered, slit-like chamber that may not be demonstrable with routine echocardiography. In the anatomical heart, the chamber can usually be identified by transverse sections close to the base of the heart, across the region delimited by the anterior and posterior descending coronary arteries within the interventricular sulci (Figure 4A). With MS/AA, the LV may be flat or may be a nodular shoulder on the left-heart border, sometimes described as a “cherry pit” (Figure 4B). In the latter situation, the cavity is clearly markedly hypoplastic, but LV myocardial mass is increased with a thick, hypertrophied free wall (Figure 2). MS/AS has a similarly thick LV free wall. As emphasized by Lev, with a patent MV there is often a diffuse, gray-white rind lining the LV, variably involving the papillary muscles, chordae tendineae, and in some cases, the left atrium (Figure 2). Histologically, the rind is composed of abundant elastic tissue within a fibrous matrix, largely limited to the endocardium—hence the term endocardial fibroelastosis (Figure 5). On echocardiographic imaging, EFE appears as an echo bright LV lining. EFE is not seen with an MA. The etiology of EFE remains unknown but postulated pathogenetic factors include elevated LV end-diastolic pressure and myocardial ischemia.13 Chronic myocardial ischemia may be seen in MS/AA or MS/AS with fibrous scarring and myocyte dropout, more likely attributed to acquired postnatal physiological changes and/or coronary abnormalities, as described below.

Abbreviations: HLHS, hypoplastic left-heart syndrome; LV, left ventricle; MV, mitral valve.

Histological section of the LV with marked endocardial fibroelastosis (arrowheads). The arrows point to an anomalous coronary fistula in the LV myocardium connecting with the cavity. Movat stain, 20× original magnification.
Abbreviation: LV, left ventricle.

sec.title: Left Atrium
sec.p: The left atrium in HLHS is often moderately hypoplastic but remains functionally adequate. EFE may involve both LV and, less commonly the left atrium. Although EFE compromises LV function, the significance of atrial involvement is less apparent. Significant left-atrial myocardial hypertrophy may be present, most often in the setting of MA, and particularly when there is premature closure of the foramen ovale (see below).

sec.title: Atrial Septum
sec.p: In the presence of severe obstruction on the left side of the heart, left to right blood flow across the foramen ovale serves as an important, if not only, pathway for pulmonary venous blood to exit the heart. When thin and delicate, the valve of the foramen provides little resistance to this reversed, in-utero blood flow pattern with no untoward prenatal effects (Figure 6A). However, the valve may become thickened and partially muscularized, with a restrictive foramenal orifice (Figure 3B). In some cases, the foramen prematurely closes, leaving no interatrial pathway (Figure 6B). With in-utero closure, there are severe secondary pulmonary venous hypertensive changes with lymphangiectasis within the lungs, all of which contribute to postnatal morbidity and mortality. Early in the postnatal period, infants with HLHS and premature closure of the foramen ovale rapidly decompensate. Emergent creation of an atrial septostomy is required, in some cases with atrial septal stenting. If there is significant left-atrial EFE, transcatheter septostomy creation may be difficult (Figure 6B). Atrial septectomy is an important part of the first-stage Norwood procedure to relieve any potential obstruction to pulmonary venous outflow to the right side of the heart. Infants born with an intact atrial septum have been reported to have increased mortality at every stage of HLHS palliative repair, likely the result of decreased tolerance of alterations in systemic and pulmonary vascular resistance.14

caption.p: The atrial septum in HLHS: (A) The probe extends through the foramen ovale into the left atrium. The normal valve of the foramen is a semitransparent membrane (asterisk). (B) The left atrial surface of a prematurely closed foramen ovale has a concave depression (asterisk), with marked gray-white thickening of the endocardium.
Abbreviations: HLHS, hypoplastic left-heart syndrome; LV, left ventricle.

sec.p: Another common atrial septal anomaly in HLHS is posterior and leftward malalignment of the posterosuperior margin of the valve of the foramen ovale (septum primum). This creates an exaggerated recess in the RA between the muscular rim of the septum (limbus fossa ovalis or septum secundum) and the valve of the foramen. Although this is of no apparent functional significance, it does contribute to the diminished size of the left atrium and should be recognized with interventional attempts at atrial septostomy and surgical atrial septectomy.

sec.title: Pulmonary Veins
sec.p: Pulmonary vein anomalies are rare, but well recognized, in HLHS, usually when there is severe obstruction to pulmonary venous outflow, as with an intact atrial septum. The pulmonary veins normally connect with the left atrium, but an alternate systemic venous route of pulmonary venous drainage may persist. Typically, there is an anomalous vein that connects the left atrium or left-upper pulmonary vein with the innominate vein, referred to as a persistent levoatrial cardinal vein.

sec.title: Coronary Arteries
sec.p: The presence and impact of coronary anomalies on morbidity and mortality in HLHS is a subject of ongoing debate.12,15,16 The most common coronary anomaly is a sinusoidal connection (ventricular-coronary fistula) between the LV cavity and a coronary artery. These fistulas are much more common with AA/MS12,15,16 (Figure 5). In a recent review of 216 HLHS postmortem hearts with AA, ventricular-coronary fistulas were seen in 29% of 134 cases with MS.12 A spectrum of other coronary anomalies was seen in 12% of the remaining hearts with MA, but no fistulas were identified. These anomalous fistulous connections between the hypoplastic LV cavity and a coronary artery are analogous to the coronary anomalies seen in pulmonary valve atresia with intact ventricular septum and a hypoplastic RV. Although dysplastic mural thickening with luminal compromise may be seen in the affected coronary artery, this occurs much less frequently than seen in a hypoplastic RV. Intramural coronary artery branches may also have dysplastic mural thickening. Rarely, with proximal and/or ostial obstruction, perfusion of a coronary artery may be exclusively dependent on a coronary fistula arising from the hypoplastic LV.12 Compromised perfusion of the LV will lead to acute or chronic myocardial ischemia.

sec.title: Ascending Aorta and Arch
sec.p: Marked hypoplasia of the ascending aorta is an intrinsic, required component of HLHS. In AA, the ascending aorta measures only 0.2 to 0.3 cm in external diameter, with a similar to minimally larger caliber in severe AS (Figures 1 and 2). This miniscule ascending aorta serves only as a conduit for retrograde perfusion of the coronary arteries via the patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). Although always larger than the ascending aorta, the aortic arch is usually also variably hypoplastic. A coarctation ridge, typically positioned opposite the orifice of the PDA (juxtaductal), may be seen in more than 70% of cases17 (Figure 1B). Hypoplasia with an abnormally elongated (greater than 0.5 cm) segment of the arch is referred to as tubular hypoplasia. This configuration, previously termed infantile coarctation, variably affects the distal transverse arch, aortic isthmus, or both segments of the arch. Obstruction may also occur at the junction of the ascending aorta with the transverse aortic arch, a feature which led to modification of early versions of the Norwood aortic reconstruction.18

sec.title: Ductus Arteriosus
sec.p: In HLHS, the virtual or complete absence of outflow from the LV requires a persistent PDA. Perfusion of the systemic circulation and coronary arteries is dependent on right to left shunting across the PDA. The PDA is a muscular artery with abundant loose myxoid intimal tissue (intimal cushions) that approximate one another and functionally obliterate the lumen with constriction of its wall. Anatomical PDA closure involves a more complex interplay of signals and tissue responses, ultimately resulting in a fibrous cord or ligamentum arteriosus. The intimal cushions may extend along the surface of the adjacent aorta and coarctation ridge, contributing to arch obstruction. The PDA may be tortuous and, rarely, aneurysmally dilated. Ductal constriction commonly heralds cardiopulmonary decompensation in HLHS.

sec.title: Right-Sided Cardiac Chambers
sec.p: The volume load on the right side of the heart that accompanies the obligate left to right shunt across the atrial septum in HLHS results in dilation and hypertrophy of the RA and RV with dilation of the main pulmonary artery. The apex of the heart is formed exclusively by the RV, which may wrap around the displaced LV apex.

sec.title: Tricuspid Valve (TV) and Pulmonary Valve
sec.p: The TV and pulmonary valve are most often structurally normal, although both valve annuli are dilated. Some degree of TV dysplasia may be seen in up to one-third of cases of HLHS, most often in those with a patent MV.19 Valvar dysfunction is typically regurgitation and may relate to either RV dilation and/or TV dysplasia.20 In the latter case, the dysplastic leaflets are thickened and poorly mobile, often with nodular redundancy along the closing margins (Figure 7). Chordae tendineae may also be shortened, thickened, and variably fused. TV regurgitation is a significant cause of morbidity and mortality in HLHS that may require valvuloplasty or, with persistent RV dysfunction, cardiac transplantation.21

caption.p: The opened and dilated RA and RV in a heart with HLHS and TV regurgitation: the TV leaflets are thickened and redundant with short chordae tendineae and poorly formed papillary muscles.
Abbreviations: RA, right atrium; RV, right ventricle; HLHS, hypoplastic left-heart syndrome; TV, tricuspid valve.

sec.p: The most common pulmonary valve abnormality is a bicuspid valve, seen in 4% of 230 cases in 1 postmortem series of HLHS.22 Dysplastic thickening of the valve cusps with pulmonary stenosis is rare, but when it occurs, Norwood palliation may not be possible.23

sec.title: Borderline LV Hypoplasia
sec.p: A ventricle whose size is in between that clearly too small to support the circulation (ie, HLHS) and that of a mildly hypoplastic, but adequately sized, chamber falls into the gray zone of borderline LV hypoplasia. Upward of 65% of cases have been suggested to have borderline LV hypoplasia.24 The quandary faced with these intermediately sized ventricles is whether surgical repair of the associated lesions will entail a Norwood single-ventricle palliation, cardiac transplantation, or interventions to relieve obstruction, resulting in a preferred biventricular circulation. In this section, only left-sided obstructive lesions with an intact ventricular septum and a borderline LV will be discussed. Malformations that fit this category are critical AS, Shone’s complex, and aortic coarctation combined with either MS or AS. Patients with these malformations often present clinically in heart failure with elevated pressures in the LV and pulmonary venous and arterial circulations and a poorly compliant LV. These hemodynamic alterations, combined with left to right shunting across a patent foramen ovale, may lead to decreased filling of the LV, contributing to diminished LV size. RV volume overload with dilation and hypertrophy of the chamber will alter the ventricular septal geometry, resulting in an exaggerated convex leftward contour. In this setting, LV compression may also significantly compromise LV size. Borderline LV hypoplasia with an underfilled and/or “squashed” LV may respond to therapeutic interventions to alter hemodynamics and transition to a functionally adequately sized ventricle. Balloon dilation of the aortic valve is one such intervention with critical AS. This intervention may be life saving in the neonate and, when performed in the fetus, may permit sufficient LV growth for biventricular postnatal repair.5 Ballooning and/or surgical repair of coarctation of the aorta will also alter LV hemodynamics, leading to enhanced LV size. Aortic coarctation will be discussed under mild LV hypoplasia, the more common phenotype seen with this malformation.

sec.title: Critical Aortic Valve Stenosis
sec.p: Critical AS with a patent MV is the most commonly encountered lesion associated with a borderline LV24,25 (Figures 8A-8D). AS, described as critical, implies that blood flow across the valve is severely limited to the extent that perfusion of the systemic circulation is dependent on a PDA. The valve morphology will resemble the dysplastic changes seen with HLHS; however, the valve annulus and cusps are usually larger (Figure 8C). LV size in hearts with critical AS ranges from normal, or even dilated, to the full spectrum of LV hypoplasia.26 A number of clinical studies have attempted to identify objective measurements of LV size that correlate with ventricles suitable for a biventricular repair. The importance of LV inflow dimensions has been emphasized, variably assessed by noting whether or not the LV forms the apex, if the LV inflow length exceeds 25 mm, or if the ratio of the LV long axis to the heart long axis exceeds 0.8.25 Other suggested size-related parameters include the diameters of the MV (greater than 9-11 mm) and aortic valve (greater than 5–6 mm).25

The ascending aorta (Ao) is also moderately hypoplastic with dilation of the RV and pulmonary artery (Pa). (B) Left lateral view of moderately hypoplastic LV with diffuse endocardial fibroelastosis (arrowheads). (C) The aortic valve of the heart in (A) has dysplastic thickening of the cusps (arrow) and marked endocardial fibroelastosis (arrowheads). (D) The MV of the heart in (A) also has dysplastic thickening of the leaflets and chordae tendineae.
Abbreviations: LV, left ventricle; RV, right ventricle; MV, mitral valve.

sec.p: Although LV size is important, it is only one of several anatomical variables that affect the success of a biventricular repair. LV EFE as well as additional sites of obstruction involving the MV and aortic arch provide significant challenges25,27,28 (Figure 8B-8D). EFE impairs both systolic and diastolic LV function and, as such, is a major limiting risk factor for independent LV function.24,25,27,28 EFE resection may be part of biventricular repair, in an attempt to both improve LV function and enlarge the cavity.24,28 The sharp interface between the thickened, rind-like endocardium and underlying myocardium facilitates surgical dissection. However, the extent of the EFE, particularly in the LV outflow tract, may be difficult to access and resect, necessitating reoperation.28 Additional potential obstructive lesions involving the MV apparatus and aortic arch are similar to those seen in HLHS. Pathological changes in chordae tendineae and papillary muscles may be the most problematic, limiting leaflet mobility and directing MV inflow toward the posterior free wall rather than to the apex.28 Obstructive lesions in the LV outflow tract may further complicate the LV anatomy, including a subaortic membrane, muscular ridge, or anomalous chordal attachments from the MV.28 Repair of these additional obstructions may require a staged approach for biventricular repair or may be the source of recurrent obstruction, necessitating reinterventions.6,24,28 The constellation of coexisting lesions, most notably EFE, makes critical AS the most challenging lesion associated with borderline LV hypoplasia.

sec.title: Shone’s Complex
sec.p: Shone’s complex, first described in 1963, refers to a constellation of multiple levels of left-sided obstructive lesions to include a supravalvular MV ring, parachute MV, subaortic stenosis, and coarctation of the aorta29 (Figures 9A-9D). Classic Shone’s complex has all 4 lesions. In the original report, cases having 2 or 3 of the lesions were referred to as a partial, or forme fruste, version of the complex.29 All cases had a supravalvular MV ring and subaortic stenosis. The complex may be associated with a wide spectrum of LV sizes. Those with a severely hypoplastic LV may be considered to have a HLHS variant. Since the original description, the defining lesions of Shone’s complex have been broadened to include supravalvular aortic stenosis and tunnel subaortic stenosis.30 Although a parachute MV usually has a single papillary muscle to which chordae tendineae from both leaflets converge, in some cases, 2 closely apposed papillary muscles may simulate the same pathology and MV dysfunction. The MV may also be dysplastic with thickened leaflets and short, variably thickened and fused chordae tendineae, as previously described for the MV in HLHS29,30 (Figure 9A). The supravalvular MV ring may be circumferential or only partial, in which case there may be little to no associated obstruction.29 All components of Shone’s complex are often amenable to surgical correction, with initial interventions most often directed at the aortic arch.30-32 The MV apparatus may be the most challenging repair, particularly in infants.31,32 As with other left-sided obstructive lesions, RV dilation and hypertrophy from pulmonary hypertension may “squash” the LV, contributing to the degree of hypoplasia (Figures 9C and 9D).

(B) LV outflow tract with subaortic obstructive fibromuscular ridge (arrowheads). (C) The RV is dilated and markedly hypertrophied secondary to pulmonary arterial and venous hypertension. sec.title: Mild LV Hypoplasia
sec.p: Mild LV hypoplasia may be associated with obstruction to LV inflow, outflow, or the aortic arch. Inflow lesions include cor triatriatum and isolated MS. As previously described, AS may have mild LV hypoplasia. Aortic coarctation is the most common left-sided obstructive lesion associated with mild LV hypoplasia (Figures 10A-10D).

caption.p: Aortic coarctation with mild LV hypoplasia: (A) External view of the heart with arrow pointing to LV apex. The RA, RV and pulmonary artery (Pa) are dilated with moderate hypoplasia of the ascendin aorta (Ao). (B) A close-up view of the opened aortic arch with arrowheads outlining the coarctation ridge. The ridge sits opposite the orifice of the PDA. The opened RV is dilated (C) and the opened LV (D) is mildly hypoplastic.
Abbreviations: LV, left ventricle; RV, right ventricle; RA, right atrium; PDA, patent ductus arteriosus.

sec.title: Coarctation of the Aorta
sec.p: Aortic coarctation may occur as an isolated lesion; however, additional sites of arch and LV inflow or outflow obstruction are common. Proximal to the discrete coarctation ridge, there may be tubular hypoplasia, referred to as infantile coarctation, as described in classic HLHS. Nearly 50% to 60% of cases have a bicuspid aortic valve, with most (90%) having a poorly developed intercoronary commissure or raphe.33 Rarely, the valve is unicommissural. Valvar AS occurs in a minority of patients. Subvalvar AS, in the form of a fibrous or muscular ridge and/or tunnel-like narrowing, may require resection or a more complex repair (Konno procedure) to enlarge the outflow tract. MV abnormalities are described in 20% to 80% of cases, largely varying with clinical versus postmortem series.33 The anomalies include parachute deformities and short, thickened chordae tendineae. The aortic arch, aortic valve, and MV all tend to be decreased in size, though not necessarily stenotic. With aortic coarctation as the predominant malformation, additional sites of left-sided obstruction may not be evident in initial echocardiographic studies, but most will manifest clinically in the first year of life.33 Although not considered for further discussion in this review, a VSD may be present in 50% of hearts with aortic coarctation.33 LV hypoplasia associated with aortic coarctation can be quite variable; however, parameters predictive of an inadequately sized LV with critical AS do not apply to this lesion.25,34 Under filling of the LV with left to right shunting across the atrial septum contributes to LV hypoplasia in coarctation. Normalization of LV preload with coarctation repair most often results in an adequately sized LV.

sec.title: Hypoplastic Left-Heart Complex
sec.p: In 1998, the term hypoplastic left-heart complex (HLHC) was proposed for a group of hearts with hypoplasia of left-heart structures, including the MV, aortic valve, ascending aorta and aortic arch but no intrinsic valvar stenosis.1,25 Arch anomalies largely constitute this group of hearts, including arch atresia, interruption, hypoplasia, and coarctation. There is forward flow through the ascending aorta; however, the descending aorta may be PDA dependent. As with arch anomalies in general, a VSD may be present, in which case, there may also be subaortic obstruction related to posterior deviation of the outlet conal septum into the LV outflow tract. Biventricular repair for these malformations is typical, with normalization of LV size.1,25 Tchervenkov and colleagues1 proposed the term HLHC and considered these cases to be a subset of HLHS, representing the mild end of the spectrum. This viewpoint remains controversial, and the term HLHC has not been widely accepted.

sec.title: Other Anomalies With LV Hypoplasia
sec.p: A spectrum of other anomalies, both cardiac and extracardiac, may be associated with varying degrees of LV hypoplasia. Compression and decreased filling of the left side of the heart leads to LV hypoplasia in total anomalous pulmonary venous connection and left-sided diaphragmatic hernia.35,36 Hypoplasia in these anomalies is mild and normalizes with repair of the defect. Two other anomalies warrant specific mention as associated LV hypoplasia may be severe with impact on surgical repair and mortality. In atrioventricular canal defects, unbalanced, predominant inflow into the RV is associated with some degree of LV hypoplasia in 29% of cases and may be severe enough to preclude biventricular repair.37 Double-outlet RV may have LV hypoplasia of variable severity in 30% of cases, attributed to associated MS, MA, LV outflow obstruction caused by anomalous MV attachments, a restrictive VSD, or more rarely, an intact ventricular septum.38

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Obstructive lesions in the systemic circulation provide many challenges for clinical management and surgical repair. As detailed in this review, the obstructions are complex and often multiple, involving LV inflow, outflow, and the aortic arch. LV hypoplasia adds an additional layer of complexity. The pathological spectrum of LV hypoplasia is quite broad and includes both fixed anatomical and functional hemodynamic components. New therapeutic interventions, including fetal procedures, are expanding the spectrum of lesions and LV sizes that may be amenable to a biventricular repair. Demonstration of the pathological anatomy of LV hypoplasia facilitates understanding of this spectrum of lesions.
